z:row.Keyword: computational geometry|number theory|quantisation (signal)|roundoff errors|signal processing|symbol manipulation
z:row.Abstract: Depending on the kind of calculation we're performing, the loss of precision could lead to disastrous results. Symbols permit many kinds of arithmetic to be simplified and allow otherwise unwieldy expressions to be expressed. These symbols are handy for conceptual and continuous time, but do us little good when it comes to finite, real-world signal processing. This is where we meet quantization-the process of storing information. In this article, I deal with the consequences of quantization-in other words, the effects of the data word in memory. In digital signal processing (DSP), limited resolution can result in anything from limit cycles and oscillations to phase and magnitude distortions in reproduced signals. I examine this issue from the ground up, as quantization is a constant subtext in any analysis or algorithm. To get a feel for the effects of quantization on a process, consider what it would take to construct a circle from line segments. Line segments are essentially what we deal with in finite processing. Each data point is separate, and we use these points by drawing a line between them. If we wish to plot the signal from the captured data points as our DSP sees it, we must take a ruler and connect the data points on a graph. If we wish to approximate a circle constructed of data points, we would connect them with a straight line as well. The quality of our circle, then, depends upon the number of our data points. With fewer data points, our approximation is coarser and the circle is less round and more polygonal. To get a better sense of what we are dealing with, I review some basic concepts of numerics
z:row.User2: circle chording; precision loss; symbol manipulation; signal quantization; information storage; data word effects; digital signal processing; limited resolution; limit cycles; oscillations; phase distortions; magnitude distortions; reproduced signals; line segments; finite processing; captured data points; approximate circle; polygonal approximation; numerics

z:row.TitlePrimary: Search algorithms for model-based SAR ATR
z:row.TitleSecondary: Algorithms for Synthetic Aperture Radar Imagery III, 10-12 April 1996
z:row.TitleTertiary: Proc. SPIE - Int. Soc. Opt. Eng. (USA)
z:row.Keyword: Bayes methods|image recognition|prediction theory|radar imaging|radar target recognition|search problems|synthetic aperture radar
z:row.PeriodicalFull: Proceedings of the SPIE - The International Society for Optical Engineering
z:row.Abstract: The Wright Laboratory/DARPA MSTAR program is developing an innovative model-based vision approach to SAR ATR. Central to that approach is the PEMS (predict-extract-match-search) subsystem that implements a “hypothesis and test” approach to target recognition. The search module directs the search through hypothesis space and seeks to minimize the computational effort of that search. This paper presents the key concepts and issues behind the design of the MSTAR Search module
z:row.User2: search algorithms; model-based SAR ATR; Wright Laboratory/DARPA MSTAR program; model-based vision approach; PEMS; predict-extract-match-search subsystem; hypothesis and test approach; search module; hypothesis space; computational effort; MSTAR Search module; Bayesian reasoning

z:row.TitleSecondary: Proceedings of the American Institute for Decision Sciences Ninth Annual Meeting Western Regional Conference, 12-14 March 1980
z:row.TitleTertiary: Proceedings of the American Institute for Decision Sciences Ninth Annual Meeting Western Regional Conference
z:row.Author_Address_Affiliation: Univ. of Wisconsin, Oshkosh, WI, USA
z:row.Abstract: The project described in this paper was part of an operations analysis course in the MBA program at the University of Wisconsin-Oshkosh. Students were required to find a real-world problem, analyze it, give class representations, and develop solution models. The particular problem discussed involved scheduling the planting for a rather large commercial greenhouse using actual data from the company. The problem in an excellent example of the conflicting goals of utilizing capacity, doing things `as we always have', and attempting to maximize profits. The approach presented utilizes linear programming but simulation could also be used in a case approach
z:row.User2: profit maximisation; modelling; commercial greenhouse; operations analysis; scheduling; linear programming

z:row.TitlePrimary: Spin transitions in the FexMn1-xS2 system
z:row.Keyword: ANTIFERROMAGNETIC PHASE-TRANSITION|BRILLOUIN-ZONE INTEGRATIONS|TOTAL-ENERGY CALCULATIONS|AUGMENTED-WAVE METHOD|X-RAY-DIFFRACTION|HIGH-PRESSURE|IRON PYRITE|ELECTRONIC-STRUCTURE|METAL SULFIDES|BASIS-SET|Physics, Condensed Matter
z:row.PlaceOfPublication: COLLEGE PK; ONE PHYSICS ELLIPSE, COLLEGE PK, MD 20740-3844 USA
z:row.Author_Address_Affiliation: MIT, Dept Mat Sci & Engn, Cambridge, MA 02139 USA. Univ Wisconsin, Dept Mat Sci & Engn, Madison, WI 53706 USA.; Persson, K, MIT, Dept Mat Sci & Engn, 77 Massachusetts Ave, Cambridge, MA 02139 USA.
z:row.Abstract: Pressure-induced spin transitions of the Fe2+ and the Mn2+ ions in the FexMn1-xS2 system are investigated using calculations based on density-functional theory within the generalized gradient approximation (GGA)+U formalism. MnS2 shows a transition from a high-spin to a low-spin state at high pressure. The transition pressures decrease with increasing Fe content, and at high Fe content, transition pressures approaching zero are obtained. However, the volume change at the transition remains remarkably constant as long as both Fe and Mn participate.

z:row.TitlePrimary: Phase stability of nickel hydroxides and oxyhydroxides
z:row.PlaceOfPublication: PENNINGTON; 65 SOUTH MAIN STREET, PENNINGTON, NJ 08534 USA
z:row.Author_Address_Affiliation: Univ Michigan, Dept Mat Sci & Engn, Ann Arbor, MI 48109 USA. Univ Wisconsin, Dept Mat Sci & Engn, Madison, WI 53706 USA. MIT, Dept Mat Sci & Engn, Cambridge, MA 02139 USA.; Van der Ven, A, Univ Michigan, Dept Mat Sci & Engn, Ann Arbor, MI 48109 (TRUNCATED)
z:row.Abstract: We investigate phase stability of several nickel hydroxides from first-principles. Hydrogen removal from beta-Ni(OH)(2) is predicted to occur through a biphasic reaction to beta-NiOOH involving a change in the stacking sequence from T1 [for beta-Ni(OH)(2)] to P3 (for beta-NiOOH). Further topotactic removal of hydrogen from beta-NiOOH can only occur after a step in a range between 0.4 and 0.9 V is surpassed. We also propose an energetically stable crystal structure for stoichiometric gamma-NiOOH, which offers an explanation for the oxidation limit of 3.66 for Ni. In this structure, potassium in the intercalation layer resides halfway between adjacent trigonal prismatic sites. We conclude with a discussion of the role of the electrolyte in determining phase stability as well as the voltage profile of gamma-NiOOH. (c) 2005 The Electrochemical Society. [DOI: 10.1149/1.2138572] All rights reserved.
z:row.Notes: PT: J; CR: BARDE F, 2004, CHEM MATER, V16, P3936 BARDE F, 2005, CHEM MATER, V17, P470 BLOCHL PE, 1994, PHYS REV B, V50, P17953 BODE H, 1966, ELECTROCHIM ACTA, V11, P1079 BUTEL M, 1999, SOLID STATE IONICS, V122, P271 CARLIER D, 2003, CHEM MATER, V15, P2651 CEDER G, 2000, MODEL SIMUL MATER SC, V8, P311 COCOCCIONI M, 2005, PHYS REV B, V71 CORRIGAN DA, 1989, J ELECTROCHEM SOC, V136, P613 DEDOMPABLO MEA, 2002, PHYS REV A, V60 DEMOURGUES A, 1997, NUCL INSTRUM METH B, V133, P39 DESILVESTRO J, 1988, J ELECTROCHEM SOC, V135, P885 GABRISCH H, 2002, ELECTROCHEM SOLID ST, V5, A111 KRESSE G, 1996, COMP MATER SCI, V6, P15 KRESSE G, 1999, PHYS REV B, V59, P1758 LEGER C, 1999, J ELECTROCHEM SOC, V146, P924 OLIVA P, 1982, J POWER SOURCES, V8, P229 REED J, 2002, ELECTROCHEM SOLID ST, V5, A145 VANDERVEN A, 1998, PHYS REV B, V58, P2975 ZHOU F, 2004, PHYS REV B, V70; NR: 20; TC: 0; J9: J ELECTROCHEM SOC; PG: 6; GA: 001NK

z:row.TitlePrimary: Instability of Pt/C electrocatalysts in proton exchange membrane fuel cells - A mechanistic investigation
z:row.Keyword: SURFACE-AREA LOSS|GRAPHITIZED CARBON-BLACK|PHOSPHORIC-ACID|OXYGEN|REDUCTION|PLATINUM DISSOLUTION|CRYSTALLITE GROWTH|PARTICLES|CATALYSTS|PEMFCS|ELECTROLYTE|Electrochemistry|Materials Science, Coatings & Films
z:row.PlaceOfPublication: PENNINGTON; 65 SOUTH MAIN STREET, PENNINGTON, NJ 08534 USA
z:row.Author_Address_Affiliation: MIT, Cambridge, MA 02139 USA. Univ Wisconsin, Madison, WI 53706 USA. Gen Motors Fuel Cell Act, Honeoye Falls, NY 14472 USA.; Ferreira, PJ, Univ Texas, Austin, TX 78712 USA.; shaohorn@mit.edu
z:row.Abstract: Equilibrium concentrations of dissolved platinum species from a Pt/C electrocatalyst sample in 0.5 M H2SO4 at 80 degrees C were found to increase with applied potential from 0.9 to 1.1 V vs reversible hydrogen electrode. In addition, platinum surface area loss for a short-stack of proton exchange membrane fuel cells (PEMFCs) operated at open-circuit voltage (similar to 0.95 V) was shown to be higher than another operated under load (similar to 0.75 V). Both findings suggest that the formation of soluble platinum species (such as Pt2+) plays an important role in platinum surface loss in PEMFC electrodes. As accelerated platinum surface area loss in the cathode (from 63 to 23 m(2)/g(Pt) in similar to 100 h) was observed upon potential cycling, a cycled membrane electrode assembly (MEA) cathode was examined in detail by incidence angle X-ray diffraction and transmission electron microscopy (TEM) to reveal processes responsible for observed platinum loss. In this study, TEM data and analyses of Pt/C catalyst and cross-sectional MEA cathode samples unambiguously confirmed that coarsening of platinum particles occurred via two different processes: (i) Ostwald ripening on carbon at the nanometer scale, which is responsible for platinum particle coarsening from similar to 3 to similar to 6 nm on carbon, and (ii) migration of soluble platinum species in the ionomer phase at the micrometer scale, chemical reduction of these species by crossover H-2 molecules, and precipitation of platinum particles in the cathode ionomer phase, which reduces the weight of platinum on carbon. It was estimated that each process contributed to similar to 50% of the overall platinum area loss of the potential cycled electrode. (c) 2005 The Electrochemical Society.
z:row.Notes: PT: J; CR: ARAGANE J, 1988, J ELECTROCHEM SOC, V135, P844 ARAGANE J, 1996, J APPL ELECTROCHEM, V26, P147 BETT JA, 1974, J CATAL, V35, P307 BETT JAS, 1976, J CATAL, V41, P124 BINDRA P, 1979, J ELECTROCHEM SOC, V126, P1631 BLURTON KF, 1978, ELECTROCHIM ACTA, V23, P183 BREAULT RD, 2003, HDB FUEL CELLS FUNDA, V4, P797 DARLING RM, 2003, J ELECTROCHEM SOC, V150, A1523 DARLING RM, 2005, J ELECTROCHEM SOC, V152, A242 EHRBURGER P, 1984, ADV COLLOID INTERFAC, V21, P275 FULTZ B, 2002, TRANSMISSION ELECT M GASTEIGER HA, 2003, HDB FUEL CELLS FUNDA, V3, P593 GASTEIGER HA, 2004, J POWER SOURCES, V127, P162 GASTEIGER HA, 2005, APPL CATAL B-ENVIRON, V56, P9 GOTTESFELD S, 1997, ADV ELECTROCHEM SCI, V5, P195 GRANQVIST CG, 1976, J CATAL, V42, P477 GRUVER GA, 1980, J ELECTROCHEM SOC, V127, P1219 HONJI A, 1988, J ELECTROCHEM SOC, V135, P355 KING JM, 2003, HDB FUEL CELLS FUNDA, V4, P832 KINOSHITA K, 1973, J ELECTROANAL CHEM, V48, P157 KINOSHITA K, 1990, J ELECTROCHEM SOC, V137, P845 LANDSMAN DA, 2003, HDB FUEL CELLS, V4, P811 LIFSHITZ IM, 1961, J PHYS CHEM SOLIDS, V19, P35 NEWMAN J, 2004, ELECTROCHEMICAL SYST PASSALACQUA E, 1992, ELECTROCHIM ACTA, V37, P2725 PATTERSON T, 2002, FUEL CELL TECHNOLOGY, P313 PAULUS UA, 2002, ELECTROCHIM ACTA, V47, P3787 POURBAIX M, 1966, ATLAS ELECTROCHEMICA ROSS PN, 1987, CATALYST DEACTIVATIO, P165 TADA T, 2003, HDB FUEL CELLS FUNDA, V3, P481 THOMPSETT D, 2003, HDB FUEL CELLS FUNDA, V3, P467 VOORHEES PW, 1985, J STAT PHYS, V38, P231 WAGNER C, 1961, Z ELEKTROCHEM, V65, P581 WANG T, 1985, SURF SCI, V163, P181 WILSON MS, 1993, J ELECTROCHEM SOC, V140, P2872 WOODS R, 1976, ELECTROANALYTICAL CH, V9, P1 XIE J, 2005, J ELECTROCHEM SOC, V152, A104 YU P, 2005, J POWER SOURCES, V144, P11; NR: 38; TC: 6; J9: J ELECTROCHEM SOC; PG: 16; GA: 982BW

z:row.TitlePrimary: Thermodynamics of spinel LixTiO2 from first principles
z:row.Keyword: lithium intercalation|battery material|first principles|spinel|LixTiO2|TOTAL-ENERGY CALCULATIONS|TRANSITION-METAL OXIDES|PHASE-STABILITY|AB-INITIO|INTERCALATION|LITI2O4|ELECTROCHEMISTRY|TRANSFORMATIONS|INSERTION|ANATASE|Chemistry, Physical|Physics, Atomic, Molecular & Chemical
z:row.PlaceOfPublication: AMSTERDAM; PO BOX 211, 1000 AE AMSTERDAM, NETHERLANDS
z:row.Author_Address_Affiliation: Delft Univ Technol, Fac Sci Appl, Dept Radiat Radionuclides & Reactors, NL-2629 JB Delft, Netherlands. MIT, Dept Mat Sci & Engn, Cambridge, MA 02139 USA. Univ Wisconsin, Dept Mat Sci & Engn, Madison, WI 53706 USA.; Wagemaker, M, Delft Univ Techn(TRUNCATED)
z:row.Abstract: The thermodynamic and structural properties of LixTiO2 spinel are investigated by means of a cluster expansion based on pseudopotential ground state energy calculations in the Generalized Gradient approximation (GGA). The cluster expansion enables a Monte Carlo simulation of configurational thermodynamics, giving the Li configurations, chemical potential and the insertion potential as function of Li composition at 300 K. For 1/2 < x < 1Li(x)TiO(2) we find a two-phase region, consistent with what is found experimentally. The two coexisting phases differ in the sites occupied by Li: in Li1/2TiO2 and LiTiO2 Li occupies the crystallographic 8a and 16c sites, respectively. This site occupation and the changes in the unit cell dimensions compare well with X-ray and neutron diffraction experiments. For x < 1/2 in LixTiO2 solid solution behavior is found and Li extraction can only occur at higher potentials. The potential step at Li-1/2/TiO2 is Calculated to be 1.4 V, in good agreement with experiment, but considerably higher than in the comparable Co and Mn-spinel. (C) 2005 Elsevier B.V. All rights reserved.
z:row.Notes: PT: J; CR: ASTA M, 1993, PHYS REV B, V48, P748 AYDINOL MK, 1997, PHYS REV B, V56, P1354 BENCO L, 1999, INORG CHEM, V38, P20 CAVA RJ, 1984, J SOLID STATE CHEM, V53, P64 CEDER G, 1999, ELECTROCHIM ACTA, V45, P131 COLBOW KM, 1989, J POWER SOURCES, V26, P397 DEFONTAINE D, 1994, SOLID STATE PHYS, V47, P33 GARBULSKY GD, 1995, PHYS REV B, V51, P67 GRUNES LA, 1982, PHYS REV B, V25, P7157 GUMMOW RJ, 1994, SOLID STATE IONICS, V69, P59 HOHENBERG P, 1964, PHYS REV B, V136, P864 JOHNSTON DC, 1976, J LOW TEMP PHYS, V25, P145 KRESSE G, 1996, COMP MATER SCI, V6, P15 MURPHY DW, 1982, REV CHIM MINER, V19, P441 MURPHY DW, 1983, SOLID STATE IONICS, V9, P413 RODRIGUEZCARVAJAL J, 1998, PHYS REV LETT, V81, P4660 ROSSEN E, 1993, SOLID STATE IONICS, V62, P53 SANCHEZ JM, 1984, PHYSICA A, V128, P334 TARASCON JM, 2001, NATURE, V414, P359 VANDERVEN A, 1998, PHYS REV B, V58, P2975 VANDERVEN A, 1999, PHYS REV B, V59, P742 VANDERVEN A, 2000, SOLID STATE IONICS, V135, P21 WITTINGHAM MS, 1977, J ELECTROCHEM SOC, V124, P1387 ZHOU F, 2004, ELECTROCHEM COMMUN, V6, P1144 ZHOU F, 2004, PHYS REV B, V15; NR: 25; TC: 0; J9: CHEM PHYS; PG: 7; GA: 979TN

z:row.TitlePrimary: Coarse-graining protein energetics in sequence variables
z:row.PlaceOfPublication: COLLEGE PK; ONE PHYSICS ELLIPSE, COLLEGE PK, MD 20740-3844 USA
z:row.Author_Address_Affiliation: MIT, Dept Phys, Cambridge, MA 02139 USA. MIT, Dept Biol, Cambridge, MA 02139 USA. DuPont Cent Res & Dev, Expt Stn, Wilmington, DE 19880 USA. MIT, Dept Mat Sci & Engn, Cambridge, MA 02139 USA. Univ Wisconsin, Dept Mat Sci & Engn, Madison, WI 5370(TRUNCATED)
z:row.Abstract: We show that cluster expansions (CE), previously used to model solid-state materials with binary or ternary configurational disorder, can be extended to the protein design problem. We present a generalized CE framework, in which properties such as energy can be unambiguously expanded in the amino-acid sequence space. The CE coarse grains over nonsequence degrees of freedom (e.g., side-chain conformations) and thereby simplifies the problem of designing proteins, or predicting the compatibility of a sequence with a given structure, by many orders of magnitude. The CE is physically transparent, and can be evaluated through linear regression on the energies of training sequences. We show, as example, that good prediction accuracy is obtained with up to pairwise interactions for a coiled-coil backbone, and that triplet interactions are important in the energetics of a more globular zinc-finger backbone.
z:row.Notes: PT: J; CR: ACHARYA A, 2002, BIOCHEMISTRY-US, V41, P14122 ALI MH, 2005, STRUCTURE, V13, P225 ALLERT M, 2004, P NATL ACAD SCI USA, V101, P7907 ALTHOFF JD, 1995, PHYS REV LETT, V74, P138 BLUM V, 2004, PHYS REV B, V69 BROOKS BR, 1983, J COMPUT CHEM, V4, P187 CEDER G, 1993, COMP MATER SCI, V1, P144 CEDER G, 1997, J ELECTROCERAM, V1, P15 CRICK FHC, 1953, ACTA CRYSTALLOGR, V6, P689 DAHIYAT BI, 1997, SCIENCE, V278, P82 DEFONTAINE D, 1994, SOLID STATE PHYS, V47 DESMET J, 1992, NATURE, V356, P539 DWYER MA, 2004, SCIENCE, V304, P1967 FONG JH, 2004, GENOME BIOL, V5 GARBULSKY GD, 1995, PHYS REV B, V51, P67 GOLDSTEIN RF, 1994, BIOPHYS J, V66, P1335 GUEROIS R, 2001, CURR OPIN STRUC BIOL, V11, P101 KRAEMERPECORE CM, 2001, CURR OPIN CHEM BIOL, V5, P690 KRYLOV D, 1994, EMBO J, V13, P2849 KUHLMAN B, 2003, SCIENCE, V302, P1364 LAZARIDIS T, 1999, PROTEINS, V35, P133 MCCORMACK R, 1995, PHYS REV B, V51, P15808 MENDES J, 2002, CURR OPIN STRUC BIOL, V12, P441 OSHEA EK, 1992, CELL, V68, P699 POKALA N, 2001, J STRUCT BIOL, V134, P269 RUSS WP, 2002, CURR OPIN STRUC BIOL, V12, P447 SANCHEZ JM, 1984, PHYSICA A, V128, P334 VANDEWALLE A, 2002, J PHASE EQUILIB, V23, P348 VENDRUSCOLO M, 2003, CURR OPIN STRUC BIOL, V13, P82 WOLVERTON C, 2002, ACTA MATER, V50, P2187 ZHOU F, IN PRESS; NR: 31; TC: 0; J9: PHYS REV LETT; PG: 4; GA: 969JG

z:row.TitlePrimary: First results from Viper: Detection of small-scale anisotropy at 40 GHz
z:row.Keyword: cosmic microwave background|cosmology : observations|MICROWAVE BACKGROUND ANISOTROPIES|POWER SPECTRUM|SKY MAPS|NOISE|Astronomy & Astrophysics
z:row.PlaceOfPublication: CHICAGO; 5720 SOUTH WOODLAWN AVE, CHICAGO, IL 60637-1603 USA
z:row.Author_Address_Affiliation: Carnegie Mellon Univ, Dept Phys, Pittsburgh, PA 15213 USA. Univ Colorado, JILA, Boulder, CO 80309 USA. Univ Colorado, Dept Phys, Boulder, CO 80309 USA. CALTECH, IPAC, Pasadena, CA 91125 USA. Coll France, Lab Phys Corpusculaire & Cosmol, F-75231 (TRUNCATED)
z:row.Abstract: Results of a search for small-scale anisotropy in the cosmic microwave background (CMB) are presented. Observations were made at the South Pole using the Viper telescope, with a 0 degrees.26 (FWHM) beam and a passband centered at 40 GHz. Anisotropy band-power measurements in bands spanning the range of l in which the first acoustic peak is expected (bands centered at l = 108, 173, 237, 263, 422, and 589) are reported. Statistically significant CMB anisotropy is detected in all bands.

z:row.TitlePrimary: Beam test of the ATLAS silicon detector modules
z:row.Keyword: MICROSTRIP DETECTORS|BINARY READOUT|ELECTRONICS|Instruments & Instrumentation|Nuclear Science & Technology|Physics, Particles & Fields|Spectroscopy
z:row.PeriodicalFull: Nuclear Instruments & Methods in Physics Research Section A-Accelerators Spectrometers Detectors and Associated Equipment
z:row.PlaceOfPublication: AMSTERDAM; PO BOX 211, 1000 AE AMSTERDAM, NETHERLANDS
z:row.Author_Address_Affiliation: Univ Calif Santa Cruz, SCIPP, Santa Cruz, CA 95064 USA. Univ Valencia, CSIC, IFIC, Valencia, Spain. Univ Geneva, Geneva, Switzerland. Univ Calif Berkeley, Lawrence Berkeley Lab, Berkeley, CA 94720 USA. Univ Calif Irvine, Irvine, CA USA. Univ Cal(TRUNCATED)
z:row.Abstract: Results are reported from a beam test of prototype silicon microstrip detectors and front-end electronics developed for use in the LHC detector ATLAS. The detector assemblies ("modules") were 12 cm long and were read out with binary electronics. Both irradiated and unirradiated modules were measured in a 1.56 T magnetic field for efficiency, noise occupancy, and position resolution as a function of bias voltage, binary hit threshold, and detector rotation angle with respect to the beam direction. (C) 1998 Elsevier Science B.V. All rights reserved.
z:row.Notes: PT: J; CR: BARBERIS E, 1995, NUCL INSTRUM METH A, V364, P507 DEWITT J, 1995, IEEE T NUCL SCI 1, V42, P445 DEWITT J, 1997, NUCL INSTRUM METH A, V386, P122 UNNO Y, 1996, IEEE NUCL SCI S 3 8 UNNO Y, 1996, IEEE T NUCL SCI 2, V43, P1175 UNNO Y, 1996, NUCL INSTRUM METH A, V383, P211; NR: 6; TC: 3; J9: NUCL INSTRUM METH PHYS RES A; PG: 4; GA: 103TZ

z:row.TitlePrimary: Performance of the ATLAS silicon strip detector modules
z:row.Keyword: MICROSTRIP DETECTORS|BINARY READOUT|ELECTRONICS|NOISE|Instruments & Instrumentation|Nuclear Science & Technology|Physics, Particles & Fields|Spectroscopy
z:row.PeriodicalFull: Nuclear Instruments & Methods in Physics Research Section A-Accelerators Spectrometers Detectors and Associated Equipment
z:row.PlaceOfPublication: AMSTERDAM; PO BOX 211, 1000 AE AMSTERDAM, NETHERLANDS
z:row.Author_Address_Affiliation: Univ Calif Santa Cruz, Santa Cruz Inst Particle Phys, Santa Cruz, CA 95064 USA. Univ Valencia, CSIC, IFIC, Valencia, Spain. Univ Geneva, Geneva, Switzerland. Univ Calif Berkeley, Lawrence Berkeley Lab, Berkeley, CA USA. Univ Calif Irvine, Irvine(TRUNCATED)
z:row.Abstract: The performance of the silicon strip detector prototypes developed for use in ATLAS at the LHC is reported, Baseline detector assemblies ("modules") of 12 cm length were read out with binary electronics at 40 MHz clock speed, For both irradiated and unirradiated modules, the tracking efficiency, noise occupancy, and position resolution were measured as a function of bias voltage, binary hit threshold, and detector rotation angle in a 1.56 T magnetic field, measurements were also performed at a particle Bur comparable to the one expected at the LHC. (C) 1998 Elsevier Science B.V. All rights reserved.

z:row.TitlePrimary: Phylogenetics of Seed Plants - an Analysis of Nucleotide-Sequences from the Plastid Gene Rbcl
z:row.PeriodicalFull: Annals of the Missouri Botanical Garden
z:row.PlaceOfPublication: ST LOUIS; 2345 TOWER GROVE AVENUE, ST LOUIS, MO 63110
z:row.Author_Address_Affiliation: UNIV N CAROLINA,DEPT BIOL,CHAPEL HILL,NC 27599. WASHINGTON STATE UNIV,DEPT BOT,PULLMAN,WA 99164. UNIV COLORADO,DEPT EPO BIOL,BOULDER,CO 80309. UNIV WISCONSIN,DEPT BIOL SCI,MILWAUKEE,WI 53201. DUKE UNIV,DEPT BOT,DURHAM,NC 27708. UNIV CALIF RIVERS(TRUNCATED)
z:row.Abstract: We present the results of two exploratory parsimony analyses of DNA sequences from 475 and 499 species of seed plants, respectively, representing all major taxonomic groups. The data are exclusively from the chloroplast gene rbcL, which codes for the large subunit of ribulose-1,5-bisphosphate carboxylase/oxygenase (RuBisCO or RuBPCase). We used two different state-transformation assumptions resulting in two sets of cladograms: (i) equal-weighting for the 499-taxon analysis; and (ii) a procedure that differentially weights transversions over transitions within characters and codon positions among characters for the 475-taxon analysis. The degree of congruence between these results and other molecular, as well as morphological, cladistic studies indicates that rbcL sequence variation contains historical evidence appropriate for phylogenetic analysis at this taxonomic level of sampling. Because the topologies presented are necessarily approximate and cannot be evaluated adequately for internal support, these results should be assessed from the perspective of their predictive value and used to direct future studies, both molecular and morphological. In both analyses, the three genera of Gnetales are placed together as the sister group of the flowering plants, and the anomalous aquatic Ceratophyllum (CeratophyUaceae) is sister to all other flowering plants. Several major lineages identified correspond well with at least some recent taxonomic schemes for angiosperms, particularly those of Dahlgren and Thorne. The basalmost clades within the angiosperms are orders of the apparently polyphyletic subclass Magnoliidae sensu Cronquist. The most conspicuous feature of the topology is that the major division is not monocot versus dicot, but rather one correlated with general pollen type: uniaperturate versus triaperturate. The Dilleniidae and Hamamelidae are the only subclasses that are grossly polyphyletic; an examination of the latter is presented as an example of the use of these broad analyses to focus more restricted studies. A broadly circumscribed Rosidae is paraphyletic to Asteridae and Dilleniidae. Subclass Caryophyllidae is monophyletic and derived from within Rosidae in the 475-taxon analysis but is sister to a group composed of broadly delineated Asteridae and Rosidae in the 499-taxon study.
